Maybe, like a fire, the project burned bright at first, then settled into embers. A natural thing. To fight that, we cooked up the Carpool Challenge, a blaze of competition in March. It worked, the numbers climbed again. But the fight, it was there. Holding onto the flame, against the seasons, against the pull of routine.

The truth is, folks love their cars. The freedom, the independence, it's woven into the fabric of things. To get them to leave it behind, you gotta offer something more. We gave out goodies, gift certificates for coffee and meals and massages, even a bookstore or two. Bigger prizes, though, might have done more. A bike, a hybrid, even a sleek electric car, that might have pulled folks in. The prizes, they stayed the same, a steady drip. But imagine, a gradual escalation. A whisper of a bike in December, then a hybrid in January, the electric car a prize for the bold in February. Maybe then the numbers wouldn't have fallen.

The ticker, IHF, it whispers on the wire, a cage for a phantom.  An ETF, they call it, a security, a basket of hopes woven from the threads of a hundred companies.  Like a spider’s web, it catches the market’s fly, but with less grace, less artistry.  They say it tracks an index, mimics the dance of the market, but what market? The one where men in suits whisper numbers and fortunes are lost and found like stray dogs in the night?

This IHF, it promises diversification, a shield against the storm.  But is it a shield or a shroud? It offers the liquidity of a single stock, the bite of a quick trade, the comfort of owning a sliver of a thousand dreams. But at what cost?

They speak of expense ratios, of commissions paid, of the cold hand of the market taking its due.  They speak of benefits, but benefits for whom?  The men in suits, the ones with eyes like vultures, circling the carcass of the unwary?

The ten who hold the reins, the ten who form the backbone of this beast – they’re the ones to watch.  Sixty-three percent, they say, of the IHF’s weight rests on their shoulders.  A kingmaker’s dominion, a cabal of shadows.

They dangle a promise of returns, a whisper of a higher yield, a lower beta.  But is it truth or a siren’s song, luring the innocent to their doom?  The numbers, they dance and swirl, a hypnotic waltz of percentages and probabilities.  But the heart, the human heart, it knows better.

The true test lies not in the cold logic of the spreadsheet, but in the fire of experience.  To own the ten, to hold them in your hand, not as a fraction, not as a shadow, but as whole, living things.  That is the only true measure.

The land of dreams, a place Poe called Thulé. A word borrowed, he said, from the ancients, from Virgil’s pen. An island north, they said, beyond the known world, where the Greeks had set its edge. But the whispers of a darker source, a Germanic one, echo in the shadows. Poe, a man steeped in the lore of the Germans, a kinship with their words and their ways.

Some say he was a student of Goethe, a shadow walker in the woods of his imagination. Karl J. Arndt, a scholar of the inkwell, sees the kinship in the lines of Poe’s “Politian” and Goethe’s “Mignon,” a weaving of echoes and similarities.

Goethe, the master of words, the weaver of “Faust,” a tale spun in two parts, darkness and light. In the second, a poem called “The King of Thulé.” A king, bereft of his queen, drinks deep from a goblet gifted by her hand. Grief consumes him, a slow tide pulling him under. He, too, seeks the edge of the world, a cliff overlooking the sea. He casts the goblet, a symbol of his loss, into the waves, closes his eyes, and joins the darkness.

Poe’s “Dream-Land,” a landscape of shadows, a king haunted by the ghosts of his past, a world drained of color, of joy. One might see in this king a reflection of Poe himself, a doppelganger, a mirror held up to his own sorrow, his own escape into the bottle. And the words “Thulé,” echoed in “The Pit and the Pendulum,” like a whispered warning from the abyss.

Thulé, a bookend in Poe’s poem, a haunting refrain. A land of dreams, a place of loss, a path to the edge. 

Poe, a man who walked in the shadows, who knew the heart of darkness, who found solace in the company of ghosts. He found in Goethe, a kindred spirit, a fellow traveler on the road to the unknown.

The law in this here California, it says a customer can get more than just pocket change if they fall and break their bones over a spilled applesauce.  It speaks of 'punitive damages' - a fancy name for making the store pay extra, real extra, for being careless. But to get those, the customer, Miss Palmer, she gotta prove the store manager, Mr. Martin, didn't just make a mistake, he was downright mean.  

Now, a judge ain't gonna toss this claim out quick, not on account of a spill and a broken back. To get those punitive damages, Miss Palmer gotta show that Mr. Martin knew good and well that not cleanin' up that mess could hurt somebody, but he done it anyway, on purpose. Like he was willfully blind, seein' the danger but choosin' to ignore it. 

See, she's gonna say that Mr. Martin should have known better.  He'd been told about spills before - other folks had slipped and fallen. It happened more than once, in fact. Six times in the year before Miss Palmer went tumblin' down. And yet, he dismissed it, said he was too busy eatin' his dinner. 

Now, whether the judge sees his actions as downright despicable, that's a tougher sell. But with all those accidents, it's a story that might stick.

It all happened on a Wednesday, October 13th, 5:00 p.m. Rich Wayne, a fella workin' at the store, told Mr. Martin about the applesauce spill.  Mr. Martin, he just said, "Dinner break, gotta eat." Then, 15 minutes later, Mary Haddigan, another employee, gave him the same heads-up, same answer. 

And then, at half past five, Miss Palmer came along, slipped, and went down hard.  Back cracked.  Now she's suing the store for all the pain and heartache, and maybe even some extra punishment, for the store's careless ways.

The dust of four years settled on the classroom, the air still thick with the heat of debate.  Islam. The word itself hung heavy, a question mark in the air. Was it a religion of peace, or a wellspring of violence? The question, it seemed, only deepened in the wake of the falling towers, a knife twisting in the gut of a nation. The airwaves, once choked with suspicion, now whispered of tolerance, of understanding. A black man named Obama, with a name that tasted of the East, rose to the highest office. A world turned, it seemed, on its axis.

The Prophet's story, though, that was a different beast. It clung to me, a whisper in the dark. The man I'd imagined, the sword-wielding conqueror, the one who forced his faith upon the world, was gone. In his place stood a figure of meekness, a martyr misunderstood, drawing people to him like moths to a flame. A whisper of doubt flickered. Was this the truth, or a carefully crafted image?

The parallels with the life of Jesus, they haunted me. The loaves and fishes, multiplied on command, echoed through the ages, a story spun for both.  Was this a subtle theft, a borrowing of divinity, a way to elevate Muhammad to the same plane as Christ? The thought sat like a stone in my stomach. 

Then there were the stories, whispered from one man to another, each retelling a blur of hearsay.  These were supposed to be testaments, proof of the Prophet's truth, but they felt hollow, lacking the weight of direct experience.  

But the thing that gnawed at me the most was the portrait they painted of Muhammad.  A gentle soul, wise and humble, a beacon of light. History, though, whispered a different tale, a story of conquest and violence.  A man, perhaps, who used his faith to build an empire.  Did the faithful know this history?  Or had they chosen to embrace a myth, a carefully curated image of their prophet?

The dust of the world settled on the bones of what Jesus preached.  His voice, once a clarion call, faded to a whisper in the wind of time.  Christianity, born in his image,  grew, twisted, and spread, a vine choking the saplings of his original intent.  The world turned, a wheel ever grinding, and the light of progress cast long shadows on the past.

Old ways clung to the bones of men, resistant to the wind of change. But the tide was turning.  A hunger stirred, a yearning for something lost.  A thirst for the pure spring of Jesus' words, unmuddied by the centuries of accretion.

Like a slow, inexorable flood, this yearning would rise.  It would wash over the land, erasing the mortar of dogma, stone by stone, layer by layer.  The churches, those grand monuments to tradition, would stand watch as the tide receded, revealing a truth buried beneath the silt of time.

A new dawn would break, a return to the source.  A world where the echoes of Jesus' voice rang clear, unburdened by the weight of centuries.  The churches, though still standing, would become vessels for this new understanding, their sermons echoing the simplicity of the original message.

From sea to shining sea, the faithful would gather, not as denominations, but as a single, unified voice.  Differences would dissolve, replaced by a shared understanding, a common ground forged in the crucible of history.

History itself seemed to turn in cycles, a slow, relentless dance of progress and regress.  Like the Roman Empire, once the persecutor, now the convert, the world would turn again.  The chains of the past would loosen, the shackles of tradition would fall away, and the world would be reborn in the image of the carpenter's son.  The path to this future was paved with a single, unwavering truth: a willingness to see Jesus' words not as literal pronouncements, but as a timeless reflection of the human spirit.

And then, as always, there was the beginning, the source, the echo that resonated through the ages.  Judaism, the wellspring of faith, where monotheism took root, where the scriptures whispered promises of a coming savior.

The smoke, it rose black against the sky like a shroud.  The factories, they breathed it out, this river of soot, staining the world with the greed that fueled them. Men, they craved only more, always more, and they'd grind the life out of anything to get it. The owners, they saw the workers not as men, but as cogs, expendable parts in a machine built only for profit. 

Sinclair, he saw it. He painted a picture of Packingtown, a place where the stench of blood and decay hung thick in the air.  A place where men, their bodies broken and spirits crushed, toiled for scraps of their lives.  The line between man and beast blurred in those factories, a butcher's shop more than a place of work.

The men, they worked till they bled, till their hands were raw and their backs bent double.  For what? A pittance, a cruel joke in the face of the wealth the owners amassed.  A day's notice, that's all it took to cast them out, adrift in a sea of poverty.  

No laws to shield them, no hand to lift them. Unions, they promised help, but proved to be wolves in sheep's clothing, leeches feeding on the misery they claimed to fight.

Packingtown, it was a cage, a prison of brick and steel. The workers, they were slaves in a gilded cage, their lives consumed by the insatiable hunger of the machine.  They toiled, they suffered, they died, all for the sake of the owners' insatiable desire for more.  

Sinclair, he saw the darkness, the gnawing hunger at the heart of man. He showed the world the beast within, the beast that feasts on the weak and spits on the fallen.

The world of men, it’s painted in colors, each shade a whispered truth. Fitzgerald, he knew this. He knew how to stain the canvas of his story with hues that bled into the reader’s soul, leaving a taste of ash and regret on the tongue. Take his Gatsby. A man obsessed with the shimmer of things, with the allure of the spectral green light across the bay. But Fitzgerald, he didn't stop there. He layered his story with shades of gray, of white, of a fading pink, each color a ghost story whispering in the dark.

White, that spectral purity, it clung to Daisy like a shroud. White flannels, white dresses, white faces. A uniformity that suffocated the soul. Like the endless expanse of the city, cold and sterile. Gray, it seeped into the edges of things, the forgotten faces in the crowd, the names scrawled on Nick’s timetable. A dull ache of emptiness, the weight of forgotten dreams.

Fitzgerald, he knew the power of these colors. He used them to tell a story of a man chasing a ghost, a phantom of a love lost in the bleak landscape of the past. Daisy, she was the epitome of this white-washed illusion, a beautiful shell, empty and hollow. And Gatsby, he was the fool who chased the mirage, a man consumed by the grayness, the endless pursuit of an unattainable dream.

The land sits heavy, a sun-baked weight in the San Diego hills.  A hundred and sixty acres of chaparral, brush choked with the ghosts of forgotten ranch hands and the whispers of a time before man. Tomatoes and lemons, they call it a bounty, but the land knows other truths.  There's a hunger here, a gnawing in the dust, that can't be fed by the sun alone. 

The oaks stand sentinel, their gnarled limbs clawing at a sky bleached white by the endless sun.  The air hangs thick with the scent of sage and dust, a shroud over the bones of this forgotten place.  They say the earth remembers.  And this land, it remembers the rasp of hoof on parched earth, the crackle of a flint fire, the slow, steady pulse of a life lived closer to the marrow.

They talk of organic, of a market hungry for the purity of the soil, the unsullied taste of a tomato kissed by the sun.  But the money, it's a fickle thing, doesn't come easy in these parts. The whispers in the wind speak of a different kind of wealth, the wealth of the wild, the whispers of a kangaroo rat darting through the brush, the mournful call of a frog lost in the twilight.

There's a plan, they say, a blueprint for salvation.  A web spun to protect the creatures of this forgotten land, to thread them back into the tapestry of life. But words on paper are brittle things, easily torn by the harsh winds of reality.

This land, it holds its secrets close, buried beneath layers of dust and time. It craves a different kind of stewardship, a touch that doesn't seek to exploit, but to understand, to listen to the whispers of the wind and the rustle of the sage.  The true wealth lies not in profit, but in the quiet communion with the earth, in the dance of life and death under the relentless gaze of the sun.

The wind folded across the table, a silent thing, carrying with it the dust of a thousand reckonings.  Culture, it whispered, a scalpel carving through bone and sinew, a blade that could break or build a man. It weren't some static thing, some painted signpost on the road. It was the hollowness in a man’s eye, the way he held his hand, the story etched in the lines of his face.  You couldn't squeeze it into a box, label it and hang it on a wall.  To say "all Russians were stubborn" or "all Japanese accommodating" was to spit on the wind, a truth as fleeting as smoke. 

It was the unspoken things that mattered. The weight of history in a handshake. The way a silence stretched, thick and heavy, between two men.  It was in the way a man's eyes held yours, searching, measuring, seeing not just your face but the ghost of your soul. 

You approached a foreign land, a foreign culture, with your own baggage, your own ghosts. You saw it through the lens of your own experience, but that was a flawed lens, cracked and stained. It was a dance, a delicate balance of respect and mistrust. You had to learn their language, not just the words, but the silences between them, the unspoken rules, the hidden meanings.  You had to understand their gods, their demons, their fears. 

And you had to be willing to let go of your own.

The fool, the Psalm says, he's said it in his heart: "There is no God."  That's where Anselm starts, with that empty space, that echoing silence where God ought to be. And Aquinas, too, he sees that same emptiness, though he sets about filling it not with faith, but with reason.  They both aim for the same target, this God of the Bible, this God of the Book, and the question hangs: who hits the bullseye?  

But first, a reckoning. To compare their shots, we have to assume they both believe in the same target.  A God shaped by scripture, a God with the attributes laid out in those ancient pages. Anything else, any other God, would be a phantom, a shadow in the distance, not worthy of this kind of scrutiny. 

Anselm, he speaks of God as something already known, a truth nestled deep in the mind.  He says, look within, and you'll find him. This is a God not of the stars or the stones, but of the soul, a God glimpsed in the quiet spaces between thought and feeling.  He calls it faith, this knowing without proof, this acceptance of the unseen.  

Aquinas, he wants something more solid, something you can touch, something that doesn't rely on whispers in the dark.  He builds his case on five pillars: change, cause, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony.  Each one, a brick in the wall, a step towards proving God's existence through logic, through the observable world. No need for blind leaps, no need for faith. Just reason, pure and simple.

But both men, they wrestle with the same question, the same fundamental mystery.  And neither, perhaps, provides a final answer.  Anselm's God is a whisper in the soul, a truth too vast to grasp with the mind alone.  Aquinas' God is a construct, a masterpiece of logic, but is it enough to satisfy the human heart?

The dust of ages, it clung thick to the bones of the world. A prince, they called him. Born in the shadow of the fifth century, a man marked for something more. Buddha. A name that would echo through the years, a whisper on the wind. He cast aside the trappings of kingship, sought solace in the quiet spaces between breaths. His words, they became the bedrock of a faith. Theravada, they called it, the oldest, truest path. Twenty-five hundred years, the sun has risen and set on its tenets. Yet, the world shifts, the light changes.

Even in the land of Lanka, where the waters are cut each year in a silent ceremony, a ritual born not of Buddha's own tongue, but of time and circumstance. Monks and laymen alike, they gather, a river of devotion flowing in a current not hewn by the Buddha himself. The differences, they seep into the very marrow of the faith. From the outward forms, to the heart of what it means to be free.

To understand this, we must speak of forces. Internal and external. The whispers of dissent within the fold, the echoes of change from outside its walls. Hostile forces, they seek to wound, to diminish. Benign, they tread lightly, unaware of the ripples they cast.

The core of Theravada, it lies in the refuge of the triple gem. The Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha. The Dhamma, the spoken word, the three baskets of wisdom. Suttas, Vinaya, and Abhidhamma. Metaphysics, the nature of reality, the dance between impermanence and suffering. Anatta, the absence of a permanent self. Dukkha, the inherent pain of existence. Anicca, the constant flux of all things.

The cycle of birth and death, Sansara, it grinds on. Fueled by lobha, desire, dosa, hatred, and moha, delusion. But through understanding, through the four noble truths, we can break free. Dukkha, the truth of suffering. Samudaya, the cause of suffering, attachment. Nirodha, the cessation of suffering. Magga, the path to liberation. The eightfold path, a map to navigate the treacherous terrain of the mind.

These are the seeds planted by the Buddha. They have taken root in the fertile ground of countless hearts. But the wind of change blows, and the landscape shifts.

The land to the south, it bled. An old wound, festering for nigh on sixty years. The Mexicans and the Americans, locked in a dance of hatred and hunger, from the year of the Alamo's fall to the dawn of the new century.  They drank from the same cup, but each held it with a hand stained with blood. 

The war, that was its high tide. A storm of steel and fire, swallowing land and lives.  Texas, the Southwest, all swallowed whole by the belly of the American beast. But the hunger didn't end there. Disputes, skirmishes, whispers of war on the wind, they followed like a shroud.  

Border towns bled, lawless places where men walked with the scent of gunpowder on their breath and the ghosts of vengeance in their eyes. A tangled knot of religion, culture, and greed, drawn tight by the lines on a map.  The Americans, they saw their own god in their borders, a god with an insatiable appetite.  The Mexicans, they clung to their faith, their heritage, their land, a bulwark against the tide.  

Like two wolves circling a lone carcass, the nations snarled and spat.  The Americans, they looked south and saw opportunity, a land ripe for the taking.  The Mexicans, they looked north and saw a predator, its eyes fixed on their flesh.

Pletcher, he wrote about this, about Mexico and Cuba, two specters haunting the American dream.  He saw the same hunger in their eyes, the same thirst for power. A thirst that could never be quenched.

And the dust, the endless dust, it settled on their bones, a testament to the price of rivalry. The soil of the Southwest, red with the blood of heroes and outlaws, a silent witness to a war that never truly ended.

The sickness came on like a thief in the night, fifteen years gone now. Took hold of a nurse, the sort of woman who’d always believed in the certainties of sickness and healing. “Always work,” they’d told her, “always a need.” So she’d traded dreams of science and stories for the sterile hum of the hospital. But dreams can desert a man, even in broad daylight. 

Forty-six, alone, and the world gone gray.  No savings, no safety net, only the gnawing certainty of empty cupboards and a body that betrayed her. Fifteen years on the bones of Social Security,  barely scraping by.  Nothing left but the hollow whisper of what might have been. Every day a struggle, a whisper of doubt echoing in the silence. Nothing certain anymore.  

Except this:  she wouldn’t have made it without the ghosts of her kin, the few true friends scattered like embers in the wind. Strong?  A laugh rattling in the throat when disaster knocks. The world cracks, and you feel the tremor in your own bones. 

Big government, they say, the answer to everything. But the mortar cracks, the walls crumble, and you’re left with the echo of its promises. Better, she thought, to look to the faces around you,  the hands that offer warmth.  To learn the language of asking, of sharing the burden.

They talk of rugged individualism, the soul of this country.  But those who crossed the plains, they didn't traverse the wilderness alone. They shared the burden, the fear, the hope. Compassion, respect, those were the tools that built this land, not the iron fist of self-reliance.

Prepare, yes, be ready. A kit, candles, and a whispered prayer for strength. Preserve the harvest, learn the language of the earth. But more than that, learn the language of your neighbor.  Build bridges, not walls. For when the wind blows cold, it's the warmth of another soul that will keep you from freezing.

The question of why organisms take the forms they do, why evolution bends one way or another, has haunted thinkers for generations.  Even now, as we wield the tools of mathematics, we're only beginning to glimpse the intricate dance of form and function.  As D’Arcy Thompson wrote in 1917, "Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms."  He might say the same today. Yet, in recent years, we've begun to see how math can illuminate the grand story of life. We've used it to map the growth and lineage of mollusks, their shells whispering secrets of time and change (Raup and Stanley, 1981). Our own work seeks to unravel the mysteries of evolution in a small group of snails called Prunum. 

Imagine a shell, a spiral journey through space and time. Each loop, a whorl, encircling a central column, the columella. The speed of this spiral, the size of each whorl, the delicate suture that marks their boundaries – these are the threads that weave the tapestry of form. We use X-rays to capture the geometry of these shells, to translate the whispers of bone into the language of numbers.  We feed these numbers into powerful computers, crafting models to explore the vast possibilities of shell shape. What are the limits of change? What forces drive evolution?

And then we turn to the living world, to experiments and observations, to see how our models match the reality of Prunum. A shell is more than just a pretty thing; it’s a chronicle of growth, a record of the journey through time. We seek to read this chronicle, to understand the forces that shaped it, and to unravel the grand narrative of life etched in stone.

The dead hung heavy in the air, a stillness settling over Indonesia's children.  The numbers, they told a story of a slow bleed. Ten years, and the toll on the young remained a stagnant pool.  The world cried out for progress, for the Millennium's promises to bloom, but the blossoms here wilted. Water and sanitation, they'd reached for those stars, but the children, the mothers, they were left in the shadows, clinging to a dwindling hope.

They spoke of skilled birth attendants, seventy-two percent they said. But a midwife's hand, though gentle, can't mend a broken moon.  Hemorrhage, a silent thief, stole mothers in the dead of night, and those numbers, they whispered of a system failing, not a victory.

Diarrhea, the children's scourge, claimed its share, and the seeking of help, it dwindled.  Post-natal care, a ghost in the night, its absence a heavy shroud.

The steel kiss of the surgeon's blade, a cesarean, a rare bloom at four percent.  But the city's light, it held the promise, seven percent, while the villages, shrouded in darkness, clung to a meager two.  A chasm yawned between them, a gulf of access, a testament to a system that favored the fortunate few.

The poorest, they reached out with empty hands, a twenty-seven percent gap, a silent scream lost in the din of indifference.  Their burdens weighed heavy, out-of-pocket costs, a wall of stone, barring them from the sanctuary of care.

The question hung in the air, a shroud of despair:  should they patch the holes, program by program, or build a bridge, a sturdy foundation for a system whole?  The allure of quick fixes, of targeted interventions, it was strong.  But the siren song of progress often drowned out the whispers of long-term gain.

Resources, they were fleeting, diverted like water seeking the lowest ground.  And the human heart, it too, followed the lure of abundance, leaving behind the neglected fields of care.  Duplication, a shadow twin, stalked the corridors of aid, a web of paperwork, a testament to a system that had forgotten the art of simple compassion.

The dead, they watched, their silence a stark reminder.  The children, they waited, their hope a fragile candle in the wind.  The question remained, unanswered:  would they build a system worthy of their lives?

The shadow of Victorian convention fell long over the literature of the time, its tendrils reaching into every corner, every detail a testament to the grandeur and despair of the aristocracy. Yet, even in the heart of this gilded cage, two novels dared to break free, to burrow beneath the surface, to whisper of secrets and shadows. "Oliver Twist" and "Wuthering Heights" – tales spun not from silk and satin but from the grit and grime of the human soul. 

They are haunted by a strange and unsettling mystery, a flicker of the bizarre that shimmers beneath the surface of polite society. This darkness, this deviant whisper, serves to amplify the characters, to expose the raw nerves beneath their skin, laying bare the tangled knots of their motives and emotions.

"And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly.” (Dickens, 220)

These novels weave their mysteries into the fabric of dreams, weaving tapestries of the subconscious, where reality bends and breaks. In "Oliver Twist," these visions are a window into Oliver's soul, a reflection of his pain, his confusion, his growing awareness of the darkness that surrounds him.  The shooting that haunts him, revisited in a dreamlike haze, is a wound that refuses to heal.  He relives it, trapped in a maelstrom of senses, the "unseen hand" that carries him away a chilling reminder of his lack of control. The pain is not singular, but a constant ache, a throbbing reminder of his vulnerability. The question lingers: whose will brought about this misfortune? Is it his own, or is he a pawn in a larger, more sinister game?  

In "Wuthering Heights," the dreamlike quality takes on a more spectral form, a haunting presence that lingers at the edges of perception. Night, in its "dreadful silence" and "fleeting hours," becomes a canvas for unspoken desires and buried secrets.

The very essence of these novels lies in their ability to transcend the conventions of their time. They dare to explore the dark corners of the human heart, to expose the fragility of innocence, the corrosive power of love and revenge. They are testaments to the enduring power of storytelling, to the human need to confront the shadows within.

The air in the room hung thick with dust motes, each one a miniature sun caught in the weak rays slanting through the grimy windows.  The boy, no more than a wisp of a thing, sat hunched over a worn page, the words swimming before his eyes like drowned things. A whisper of a sigh escaped his lips. He was lost, adrift in a sea of letters that held no meaning. 

I’d seen it before, this look of bewilderment, this struggle against a language that felt as foreign as any tongue spoken on a distant shore. Adrian, they called him. A name like a melody in a language I barely understood. He spoke English, sure, but in that way a bird might mimic human speech – a shadow of the real thing.  It wasn’t until his mother came, her face etched with worry lines and her eyes filled with a silent plea, that the truth dawned on me.  

She spoke no English, only the guttural cadences of her native tongue. We exchanged words, fractured and halting, like two ships passing in the night, each searching for a common harbor. And then it hit me, a stark revelation in the dusty afternoon light: Adrian wasn’t failing to read, he was failing to decipher a foreign script. He knew the sounds, the rhythms, but not the code, the map that unlocked the secrets of the letters.

It was a simple truth, hidden in plain sight. And in that moment, I knew I had to help.  It wasn't a solution as grand as a restructuring of the entire educational system, nor a magical elixir to erase the language barrier. It was a one-on-one battle, a slow and careful teaching of the alphabet, of the sounds that formed words, of the stories that lay embedded in the spaces between those letters.

Adrian’s struggle, I realized, was a reflection of a larger truth.  Here, in this land woven with the threads of a thousand languages, we face a challenge not of weakness, but of understanding. The path forward is not a single road, but a winding path through a thousand valleys, each one demanding a different approach, a different bridge to be built. Dual language programs, immersion, tutors, ESL classes — these are not competing forces, but threads in a tapestry, each one contributing to the whole.


The key, I believe, lies in the recognition that language is not merely a tool for communication, but a gateway to understanding, a portal to the soul. Whether it’s the lilting cadences of Spanish, the guttural rasp of Arabic, or the crisp pronouncements of English, each language carries within it a universe of stories, of history, of human experience. 

And to deny a child the opportunity to unlock those universes, to navigate those landscapes of words, is to deny them a part of their heritage, a part of their humanity.

The rain fell hard against the tin roof, drumming a steady rhythm like the blood in a dead man's ears. He sat on the porch, a cigarette burning in his hand, the smoke twisting into the grey air. His father, skin stretched thin over bone, stared out at the yard, the rain blurring the edges of the world.

"What's your favorite bird?" he'd asked, voice raspy, like dry leaves skittering across gravel.

"Cardinal," the old man said, eyes still fixed on the downpour.  He didn't turn, didn't look at him. 

They sat in silence, the only sound the rain and the rasp of his father's breath.  

They were both haunted by something, something bigger than themselves, bigger than words.  Some folks called it God.  Others, ghosts.  He knew his father hadn't spoken of it in years.  He'd tried to find answers, to fill the void with something else.  Church, books, fleeting love affairs.  Nothing stuck. He was a hollow man, searching for something to hold onto in a world that didn't seem to care.

His father's hand, thin as a willow branch, reached out and rested on his knee. It was a gesture of comfort, of connection, fleeting as a butterfly's wing.  

"There's a darkness out there," his father said, his voice barely a whisper.  "It's always been there.  But sometimes, it's closer."

The rain fell harder, the wind picking up, whipping the leaves against the old house.  

The old man's hand tightened on his knee, his grip fading like a dying ember. 


He knew then that the darkness was closer now. 

He'd asked his father about God, about the meaning of it all, but the answers had always been elusive, shrouded in the same fog that now hung over his soul.  Now, he understood.  There were some things you didn't ask.  Some questions best left unanswered.



The phone call came in December. Five days after his birthday. The doctor's voice, flat and clinical, told him the fight was over. His father was gone.

He didn't go to the funeral. Couldn't.  He couldn't bear to see the empty chair, the vacant space where his father's spirit had once resided.

The notion of the Gothic novel is, in its essence and its name, a contradiction, a paradox of “Old-New,” as Ian Watt puts it in *The Rise of the Gothic Novel*. This mode of storytelling has been disparaged, lauded, accused of lacking depth, and praised for its “terrible sublime” (Burke). Horace Walpole, in *The Castle of Otranto*, the progenitor of the Gothic, wove together threads of "ancient" romantic tales and the “new” mimicry of nature found in burgeoning novels, creating a genre unto itself, a new way of telling stories. He dubbed it "A Gothic Story" (Walpole 4). Gothic derives its power from echoes of medieval Gothic theatre, architecture, and customs. Even at the time of *The Castle of Otranto*'s publication, the word "Gothic" carried a weight, used to describe a multitude of peoples, styles, and eras. It was seen as archaic, unsophisticated, a shadow of the "modern" advancements in society and literature. The merging of the theatricality of "Gothic" with the novel's form, allowing for a more intimate glimpse into the minds of its characters, is what has allowed it to endure, remaining both outdated and strangely new to readers separated from its time of origin.

One of the most persistent themes in Gothic literature is the concept of chivalry. The medieval ideal of chivalry, the training of a noble knight, is both preserved and transformed in *The Castle of Otranto*. Chivalry is particularly potent for Gothic writers because of what it represented: the quintessential knight—brave, honorable, proficient—and the perceived lack of that ideal in the society they observed (particularly by Walpole). The use of chivalric concepts and manners romanticizes the "Gothic past" (foreshadowing the evolution of Gothic into Romanticism) and attempts to elevate the present. Walpole, writing during a time of political turmoil and personal accusations, may have, consciously or unconsciously, believed that the supposed morality and inherent "goodness" embodied in the Gothic era had been lost in the individuals who made up his present society. This concept is evident in several characters, notably Frederic.

The reader is presented with Frederic's chivalric traits before even meeting him: 

The description paints Frederic with traditional chivalric imagery; he's a prince, he's suffered, been marked by tragedy, and is presumed dead at the hands of infidels. The figure of the "gallant and courteous Knight" is, of course, exaggerated, introducing the soon-to-be Gothic trope of excess (66).

The road stretched ahead, a ribbon of gray dust under a sky the color of ash. The boy walked beside him, small and silent, eyes fixed on the ground. They moved through the skeletal remains of a world stripped bare, the wind a rasping sigh through the empty husks of buildings.  This was the way now, a slow procession of broken things, a symphony of loss played on the strings of a long-dead sun. 

Supply, they called it – the way the scattered scraps of life found their way from one hand to the next, a chain forged in necessity. It was a damn fool thing, this chain. A web spun by men who thought they could control the world, but the world had other plans. 

Men like Oliver, with his words about "efficiency" and "customer satisfaction," words that echoed hollowly in this wasteland. What use were customers when the world itself was dying? What good was a well-oiled machine when the fuel was gone?

They walked on, the boy's hand in his, a small anchor in the swirling emptiness. There was a time, he remembered, when the world had been different. A time when the very air thrummed with possibility. A time when men built things, not just moved them. A time when there were forests, and rivers, and laughter that rang clear as a bell.

He stopped, the wind whipping at his face, the taste of dust and ash on his tongue.  He looked at the boy, his face pale against the grayness, his eyes wide with a question he wouldn't ask. "They say," he said, his voice a rasp, "that the chain won't break. That it stretches from hand to hand, from one end of the world to the other." 

He looked out at the wasteland, at the broken, twisted remains of what had once been. "But," he said, "I think maybe it's already broken."

The sign creaked in the wind.  A single word, scrawled in a wavering hand: "Hitler." Below it, a name: "Burma." The girl stood alone, a figure swallowed by the dust and the sun. Ellen Page, they called her. Juno, the picture on the screen, a name whispered in the dark.  But here, in this place where the air hung thick and the shadows stretched long, she was just a girl with a sign.

Burma. A land of jade and monsoon rains, a land where the mountains bled into the sky and the river snaked through the heart of the jungle. A land ruled by men who wore shadows for clothes and fear for a crown. They came to power in the blood of a coup, a whisper in the night that choked the life from the land.

They had tried to speak. The monks, cloaked in saffron, their voices rising like a prayer against the storm. A revolution whispered in the wind, a tide of voices demanding change. The "Saffron Revolution," they called it. A flicker of hope in the darkness. 

But the shadows had teeth. The army came, a tide of steel and fire. They burned the temples, crushed the whispers, drowned the prayers in blood.  

The girl on the corner, her face etched with the weariness of the world, knew this story. She knew of Kenji Nagai, his camera a witness to the violence, his life snuffed out by the shadows. She knew of Colonel Hla Win, his voice a ghost from the past, whispering of bodies counted in thousands. 

This was not new. It was the story of empires, the story of power, the story of men who claimed to rule in the name of God, who choked the light from the world. 

She thought of Tiananmen Square, the ghosts of students and intellectuals swallowed by the smoke.  She thought of Rwanda, a genocide painted in blood and tears. She remembered Hitler, his name a hiss in the dark, a nightmare that echoed through time. 

The girl with the sign felt the weight of history on her shoulders. She was a single voice in the wind, a flicker of defiance against the shadows. But even a single voice, she knew, could change the world.

The man sat hunched over the worn piano, his fingers tracing the dust motes dancing in the weak, yellow light.  Duke Ellington. His name hung in the air, a ghost in the room, like the scent of pipe tobacco and the memory of a long-gone rain.  The man knew the music, every note, every inflection.  He’d heard it in the smoke-filled clubs, in the shadows of the streets, in the hollow spaces of his own heart.  Ellington’s sound, it clung to him like a shroud.  Longevity, they called it.  But it was more than that. It was a shaping, a molding of sound, of men, into something greater than the sum of their parts.

The piano itself, a relic from a time before the ash, whispered its own stories.  Each key a weathered finger bone, each note a sigh escaping a silenced world.  Ellington’s touch, his presence, lingered in the wood, in the ivory, in the very silence between the notes.  He’d built an orchestra, not just a band, not just a collection of sounds.  He’d built a world.

The man closed his eyes, heard the muted trumpet wail, the clarinet sing, the bass rumble like a distant storm.  He saw the faces, etched in memory, the sweat on their brows, the fire in their eyes.  They were gone now, swallowed by the dust, but their music, their spirit, lived on.

Ellington understood the language of the soul.  He knew how to coax it out, how to shape it, how to give it voice.  He took the rough, the broken, the forgotten, and wove it into something beautiful, something lasting.

He’d learned to make the voice itself an instrument.  A growl, a whisper, a moan, a cry.  He’d used it to tell stories, to evoke emotions, to paint pictures with sound.  The man could hear it now, in the wind whistling through the empty streets, in the crackling of the dying fire.

Ellington’s music was a testament to the enduring power of the human spirit.  Even in the face of oblivion, of silence, of ash, the music lived on.  It was a lifeline, a beacon in the darkness, a reminder that even in the ruins, something beautiful could still be found.

The want gnawed at her, a hunger never satisfied. It started young, a flicker at fourteen, a fire by seventeen. Not for things, no. This was something deeper, a longing for a touch, a connection. Boys came and went, clumsy, fumbling things, drawn to her light but never finding purchase. She watched them, this parade of would-be suitors, and wondered at their effort, their desperate need to possess. But none held her. None stirred the emptiness within.  

Days at home were quiet, a tapestry woven with the gentle rhythms of her parents' lives. They were good people, their love a constant, unspoken presence.  But she, she thrummed with a different energy, a restless spirit that chafed against their calm.

Not today. Today, the air hung heavy, charged with an unseen tension. A scream, sharp and sudden, shattered the silence. It was her mother, her voice thin and strained.  “Mom?” she called, fear a cold fist clenching her heart.

She found her mother on the floor, crumpled and pale, clutching her side. "Ow," her mother gasped, each syllable a shard of pain. "Sweetheart... hospital..."

"Hold on, Mom, I'm getting help." 

She lifted her mother, the weight of her a familiar comfort, and carried her to the car. The hospital reeked of antiseptic and despair, but she felt only a fierce, unyielding purpose. She deposited her mother into the waiting hands of doctors, their faces grim, their movements swift.

It was a fall, a simple misstep from a rickety stool. A vase, a foolish reach. But now, the world tilted on its axis, the certainty of their tranquil life shattered.

The dust settled on a world choked by its own making.  A sun, pale and wan, hung low in a sky like old parchment. This wasn't a world of green fields and plump harvests. This was a world where the earth itself had yielded its bounty to ash. But there, amongst the ruins, a way of life clung on. A way of life measured not in calories and cholesterol, but in the slow, measured rhythm of survival. They called it the Mediterranean Diet, a whisper of the old life, a memory of sun-drenched orchards and olive groves.  Here, in this desolate landscape,  it was a testament, a defiance, a prayer against the coming night.


They spoke of it in hushed tones, this "aMed" diet, a scorecard of sustenance in a world where hunger gnawed at the edges of every day. It meant turning to the earth, to the sturdy roots and the green shoots, to the fish that swam in the few remaining pools of water. It meant favoring the fat of the olive, the oil that seeped from the earth like a promise. And it meant turning away from the flesh of the beast, from the things that choked the air with their putrescence.  

They had followed these women, these daughters of the earth, for twenty years.  Seven thousand, almost eight thousand, souls strong. Each one a story, a testament to the enduring spirit. Each one a voice whispering against the wind, a voice that spoke of resilience, of hope, of a life lived in the face of oblivion.

The women, their hands calloused, their eyes weary, filled out their records, their voices echoing in the stillness. They spoke of their meals, their days, their lives. They spoke of their losses, their triumphs, their fears. And through it all, they spoke of the aMed diet, a beacon in the darkness, a lifeline in a sea of despair.


They watched, these researchers, these chroniclers of the human spirit. They saw the women age, saw their faces etched with the lines of sorrow and the wrinkles of wisdom. They saw their bodies weaken, their limbs grow frail. But they also saw something else. They saw a strength that defied the odds, a spirit that refused to be broken. They saw the aMed diet, not just as a set of dietary recommendations, but as a symbol of hope, a testament to the enduring power of the human will.

And in the end, as the dust settled and the sun dipped below the horizon, they knew. They knew that these women, these daughters of the earth, had given them a gift. They had given them a glimpse into the heart of humanity, a glimpse into the depths of human resilience. They had shown them that even in the face of oblivion, there was beauty, there was hope, there was life.

The year was 2007. A sickness came down on the land, a fever dream of paper and ink. Houses, once symbols of hope, turned brittle and hollow. The towers of commerce, once monuments to man's ambition, shuddered and cracked. Men in suits, their faces pale and slick with sweat, whispered of numbers that meant nothing and things that didn't exist.  The air itself seemed to crackle with the avarice of it all.

They called it a crisis, a financial one, but it was more than that. It was the rot at the heart of things, the festering wound of greed that had been allowed to fester for too long. The politicians, with their empty promises and their hands outstretched for more, had fanned the flames. They'd loosened the reins, let the wolves in, and now the wolves were feasting.

The banks, fattened on easy money and reckless lending, had handed out loans like candy to anyone who'd ask. They built castles on sand, mortgages to folks who couldn't afford the shoes on their feet. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, those ghostly specters of government oversight, swallowed it all, repackaging the poison and selling it to anyone who'd buy.

And the people, blinded by the glitter and the promises of easy wealth, danced on the edge of the abyss. They bought more than they could afford, houses that were cobwebs spun from air. But the air would run out, the cobwebs would unravel, and the ground would open up to swallow them whole.

It was a slow burn, a gathering storm. And then, in the dead of night, it broke. The bubble burst. The wolves howled. And the people, they screamed. The towers crumbled, the houses fell, and the wolves feasted.

Ah, exposition. That place in your story where the words turn to dust and the reader's eyes glaze over. Where characters stand around swapping backstories like old rugs at a pawn shop.  Dr. Merlin, she's seen it all. She's heard the complaints, the sighs of boredom, the slams of laptop lids in frustrated retreat. 

Exposition ain't your friend. It's the slow, creeping fog that smothers the spark of the story.  We all know the rule: "Show, don't tell."  But sometimes, even veterans of the word wars stumble into the quicksand of too much telling.

Think of it like this: exposition is the character standing in the middle of the dusty road, spitting out a laundry list of facts about his past instead of showing you, the reader, who he is.  He tells you he's a former soldier, a failed poet, a lover of cheap whiskey and melancholic blues. You hear the words, but you don't *feel* him. You don't see the weariness etched in his eyes, the tremor in his hand, the way his soul clings to the last embers of a long-dead dream.

Take that example of the heroine, heartbroken and mourning her murdered husband.  She doesn't need to spend two pages recounting their love story. Instead, let her actions speak. Show her clutching his worn shirt, her fingers tracing the familiar scent of woodsmoke and leather. Let her gaze linger on his empty chair, her tears falling onto a half-read book.

Give the reader a glimpse of their bond through stolen glances, whispered secrets, shared laughter.  Let their love story unfold in the spaces between the words, in the unspoken language of shared memories and silent grief. 

Don't just tell the story.  Let the story breathe, let it bleed, let it live.

The flickering box in the corner spat out its news, faces washed in the pale light of the screen. A man from Ashley, Ohio, a name like a rusted hinge – Shad Hostettler – had plunged a blade into his wife.  They showed his picture, a face slack with something feral. The newsman spoke of multiples wounds, of arrest, but the details, like dust, settled quickly. Two minutes, that’s all it got. 

Then, a boy, Travis Buyers, eighteen years old, riddled with lead in the shadows of Sharon Woods. No name, no face for the boy, just the echo of a gunshot and the swift, cold touch of a SWAT team. They said the neighborhood was “rough,” a word that carried the weight of a thousand unspoken things. 

A bullet hole, a ghost in the skin of a hovering metal bird, a Med-Flight helicopter, a .22 whispering its death song.  A five thousand dollar reward, a desperate plea for whispers in the dark.

The weatherman, a man with slicked-back hair and a practiced smile, promised rain and heat. A tease, a distraction.

Then, the robbery. A man, they said, dark-skinned, a shadow in a hoodie. Six feet tall, a hundred and fifty pounds. They lingered on the darkness, the blackness, the weight of it all.

A drug kingpin from Texas, Rene Rodriguez, a name that tasted of sin and exile. He was sentenced to “three hundred” months, a number that hung heavy in the air. Hispanic, they said, a detail that had no business there.

The bond between brothers, it cuts deep. Unflinching, unyielding. A knot of things tangled tight: love, hate, envy, a touch of something mean. They see themselves in each other, clearer than any mirror. A truth laid bare when the dark comes. And that truth, it comes with a price. The cost of knowing. The cost of seeing.

You can't look into a brother's eyes without seeing your own face staring back. Not the face the world sees, but the one you try to hide. The one that bleeds out in your actions, in the dust your footsteps leave behind. 

In "The Scarlet Ibis," two boys walk a path choked with weeds and tangled vines. The air thick with the heat of a summer that will soon turn cold. They set out on a journey, a fool's errand, set by pride and shadowed by a darkness neither can name. The scorn, the fierce love, the bitter undercurrents, they all rise to the surface in the end. One brother walks away from the wreckage, the other lost to the unforgiving swamp.  

The story unfolds through the eyes of the older brother, the narrator. He is a boy consumed by pride, a heart hardened by a need to be seen, to be strong. He wants a companion who can keep pace, a mirror reflecting his own image back to him. But Doodle, his younger brother, is born frail, a fragile bird with wings too weak to fly. This pain, this frustration, it festers and grows. It poisons the air between them, thick as the humid summer air. 

The narrator's actions, his every thought, are driven by this wounded pride. He wants Doodle to be what he is not. He wants him to be strong, to be like him. He tries to force it, to mold him into his own image. But Doodle, he is a wild thing, a fragile bloom struggling to survive in a world that seeks to crush him.

And in the end, the swamp claims what it always claims. The fragile, the broken, the ones who cannot keep pace. The narrator, he is left with the echo of his brother's laughter, the taste of guilt on his tongue, and the knowledge that some bonds, no matter how strong, can be broken.

The gray matter, it thinks. A tangle of wires and whispers, a storm of lightning in the skull. Used to be they said the mind was a wax tablet, smooth and blank. Then a scroll, a book. Now they say a machine. A damned contraption of levers and gears.  They miss the point.

The senses, they come first. Sight, sound, touch, all bleeding into the darkness.  The world, a symphony of whispers, a language of flesh and shadow.  The brain, it sorts it out.  Bottom-up, they call it. Bricks laid one by one, a tower rising in the mind. But there's a hand guiding the work. A watchful eye.

Top-down they call it.  A knowingness, a darkness that sees before the light.  A knowing that the box is black, not because it is black, but because it must be. 

The mind, it filters.  A sieve through which the world is poured.  The unimportant falls away, the vital clings.  A name in the roar of the crowd, a blade of grass in the dust, a truth whispered in the dark.

But what is truth?  A memory, a ghost of what was. A story told and retold, each telling a little different.  Remember, they say.  Forgetting is a wound that never heals.  But remembering, that's a kind of forgetting too.  The past, it slips through the fingers, like smoke.

The mind, it stores.  In the crevices of the brain, in the echoes of synapses.  A library of moments, a graveyard of dreams.  But even memories fade.  The book, it falls apart, the words blur.  Only shadows remain.

How is it organized?  A web, they say.  Connections, threads spun from thought to thought.  A map of the mind, a labyrinth of the soul.  But maps lie.  And souls, they are not maps.

The mind, it is a mystery.  A dark, unknowable place.  And the more we think we understand it, the more we realize how little we know.

The man with eyes like old obsidian watched the smoke curl from the boy's cigarette. A pale ghost in the dusk. Huxley, he said, a name like dust on a windswept plain.  He spoke of a world gone soft, of flesh puppets dancing to the tune of progress. A world traded its soul for a cheap and fleeting pleasure.  

He tapped the worn paperback in his hand.  Brave New World. A world where they manufactured happiness, where the individual was a ghost in a machine.  They preached community but lived in cages of their own making.  

"He saw it coming," the man rasped, his voice a dry whisper. "The trap, the gilded cage. The hunger for more, the endless consuming.  The machine grinding on."

The boy nodded, tracing the words on the faded cover.  "They forgot what it meant to feel. To be truly alive."

"Aye," the man sighed, his gaze fixed on the dying embers of their fire. "They traded their souls for a bowl of synthetic gruel.  And Huxley, he knew the cost."

The wind picked up, a low moan through the skeletal trees.   

"He saw the world turning cold, abandoned by God. A graveyard of bones, built on the backs of the forgotten."  

The boy shivered, pulling his worn coat tighter. 

"He saw us coming," the man said, his voice a harsh whisper. "He saw the darkness gathering."  He looked at the boy, his eyes burning with a strange light. "And he warned us."

The dust of time clung to the bricks of this town, this University Park. Two years I'd walked these streets, four and a half semesters maybe, counting the slow bleed of days into each other. The campus sprawled like a wounded animal, its limbs stretching ever outward.  East Halls, they called it, where I'd first been caged like a youth.  A world away, it seemed, from the heart of things - Willard, a name that echoed with the ghosts of a thousand lectures, the Creamery, a monument to sweetness and regret, the new health services building, a testament to the fragility of our bodies. 

Back then, the land between East Halls and the rest was a wasteland, empty and untamed. Now it was choked with concrete and purpose-built dreams. A sprawling labyrinth of asphalt and brick. Getting from one place to another, it felt like traversing a continent. 

An old dog, a man not much older than myself, told me a story. Said the East Halls had once been a distant outpost, separated by acres of silence.  Now, the silence was gone, replaced by the hum of progress, the clatter of hurried steps.

I thought about it, about the time it took to get from one side of this campus to the other.  A walk to Willard from the east could be a pilgrimage, a test of endurance. Twenty-five minutes, maybe more. The wind a bitter slap against my face, the rain a cold shroud.

A friend, a man who had learned the language of the road again after years of silence, spoke of the bicycle. "It's the only way," he said, his voice weary with the wisdom of experience.

He was right. A bicycle, it is more than just a machine. It is a rebellion against the tyranny of distance, a whisper of freedom in a world that seeks to confine us.

I bought one myself, a steel horse with gears that clicked like the bones of a long-dead beast.  It transformed my world.  The twenty-five-minute slog to Thomas became a five-minute sprint. A fleeting pleasure, a stolen moment of grace. 

But the roads, they are not kind. Pollock Road, a ribbon of asphalt that cuts through the heart of the campus, a shortcut that feels like a hazard.  It demands attention, vigilance, a refusal to be consumed by the chaos.

Walking, it is a different kind of journey. A time for reflection, for the slow unfolding of thoughts. But time is a thief, and I have little to spare.  

The bicycle, it is my salvation. My chariot of fire, my escape from the tedium of endless motion. It is a reminder that there is beauty in the mundane, that even in the heart of this sprawling, grasping city, there is still a place for the wind in our hair and the sun on our faces.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
