A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

Why do organisms evolve in the manner that they do‭? ‬Are there restrictions or constraints that influence the direction of evolutionary change‭? ‬Although in‭ ‬1917‭ ‬D’Arcy Thompson stated that‭ “‬Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms‭” ‬the same can be said today. More recently,‭ ‬mathematical modeling has been applied to general aspects of mollusk skeletogenesis through both ontogeny and phylogeny‭ (‬e.g.,‭ ‬Raup and Stanley,‭ ‬1981‭)‬. Our study is exploring how mathematical modeling of ontogenetic and phylogenetic change in Prunum,‭ ‬in combination with experimental studies,‭ ‬can be used to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the direction and magnitude of evolutionary-developmental change. We used X-radiographic images of Prunum species to delineate quantitative parameters that could in turn be used to model hypothetical and actual skeletal morphologies. These parameters were entered into the software program CerioShell‭ (‬Stone,‭ ‬1995‭)‬. We modeled hypothetical shell morphologies that could be used to interpret the boundaries of possible morphological change in Prunum. These results are being combined with experimental and descriptive studies in order to better understand macroevolutionary events in this clade.

A shell can be thought of as a structure that is a tube that travels over time through‭ ‬360‭ ‬degrees of space.  These revolutions or turns of a coiled shell are called whorls,‭ ‬which are considered to spiral around an imaginary central axis.  This axis runs through the central column of the shell and is known as the columella. The speed at which the whorls enlarge can vary,‭ ‬and a continuous line separates each whorl and is referred to as a suture.  In most shells,‭ ‬the largest whorl of a shell is the last whorl‭ (‬body whorl‭)‬.  ‭ ‬The spire is considered to be all the whorls except the last. The apex is the tip of the spire and the opposite end is referred to as the base. The animal extends out of its shell through an opening called the aperture.

Shells can be viewed in apical,‭ ‬basal,‭ ‬apertural and abapertural views. ‭(‬The‭ "‬usual‭" ‬orientation of a shell is an apertural view,‭ ‬with the aperture toward the viewer and with the apex pointing up.‭)‬

A method for counting whorls is seen below.  First,‭ ‬the shell should be viewed from the apical view and then it should be determined where the first suture begins.  A line can be then drawn dividing the shell into two parts.  Whorls are counted from this line,‭ ‬and are estimated to a quarter of a whorl.

A shell can be viewed as a series of apertures that travel through time and space as the animal accretes‭ (‬i.e. builds‭) ‬its shell.  It is possible to trace the path of the aperture via coordinates of the center of each whorl’s aperture as well as the horizontal and vertical radius of the aperture.

This trajectory can be graphically and mathematically represented.  Once a mathematical formulation is made,‭ ‬it is then possible to vary parameters and modify the mollusk’s skeletogenesis.

The rate of neonatal and infant mortality in Indonesia remained rather static for the last ten years.  While the country is on track to meet many of the Millennium Development Goals, such as the water and sanitation targets, the rates of improvement for child and maternal health are woefully short of the improvements needed to meet their target goals by 2015.  The multiple reasons for these shortcomings will be discussed below, and point to a need to strengthen the health system rather than focus on programmatic interventions.
	Indonesia has made improvements in the number of births with a skilled health worker attending, with 72% of births now meeting this target.  That being said, this category still includes traditional workers, such as midwives, who cannot provide medical interventions should the pregnancy be complicated (hence the large percentage of maternal deaths caused by hemorrhage).  In other words,  the improvements made in this particular indicator are somewhat misleading and there is still much work to be done.  In addition, there has been a decline in the percentage of diarrheal cases in children under five years treated by a health professional.  While data on postnatal care is incomplete, it is clear that this area is also of concern, with low rates across the country.
	Cesarian-section rates are still lower than should be expected, around 4%.  The c-section rates additionally point to another concerning issue.  While the rate of c-section is 7% in urban settings, it is only 2% in rural.  This points to the problem of equity of coverage across the country.  Clearly access to healthcare services is focused around urban areas.  Another issue of access concerns vertical equity.  There is a 27% gap in service utilization between the poorest and richest quintiles.  Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
The dust of the road clung to my boots, a gritty echo of the wasteland. It was in the dirt, in the spines of the wind-whipped trees, that I saw it first, a truth clear and cold:  the world was broken, piece by piece, the seams splitting open. I saw it in the way folks huddled, eyes downcast, faces etched with a weariness deeper than any sun could scorch. 

And I knew then, in the marrow of my bones, that service was the only prayer left. Not the kind whispered in pews, but the kind lived out, hands calloused and worn, tending to the hurt places. This ain't no fancy notion, see. This is the gospel I preach, the creed I live by. Respect for the broken, the forgotten, the ones society casts aside. 

It ain't easy, this work. It claws at you, under your skin, in the hollow places. But it's in those dark corners, where shadows gather and whispers turn to screams, that you find the truest measure of a man. It's in the eyes of a child, scared and lost, that you see the reflection of a world gone wrong.  

I wasn't raised with silver spoons.  I seen folks fall, seen families crumble, seen the rot seep into the heart of things. College didn't offer answers, just more questions. But then, one day, I met a boy, scared and alone, caught in a web woven with pain. It was like a mirror, reflecting the darkness back at me.  And I knew, with a certainty that burned hotter than any sun, that this was my path.

I ain't one for empty words, for promises whispered on the wind. I believe in action, in the weight of a hand reaching out, in the quiet strength of a voice saying, "You ain't alone." I believe in the power of connection, of finding light in the darkest corners.

The air hung heavy with the dust of a dying world. This paper wrestles with the ghosts of sleep, the demons of insomnia, as they haunt the landscapes of both body and mind. There are two maps we must follow to understand this darkness: the map of biology, charting the terrain of genes and the flesh; and the map of culture, tracing the shadows cast by society, race, and circumstance. We'll lay bare the bones of each model, examining the research they offer, the truths they illuminate, and the mysteries they leave unsaid.

Insomnia, a thief in the night, steals the solace of sleep, leaving behind a hollow ache in its wake. It can be a solitary beast, a primary disorder, or a harbinger of deeper troubles, a symptom of mental anguish or the weight of physical illness. It claws its way into our lives through the Dyssomnias, the Parasomnias, and the lingering tentacles of other ailments. 

The biological model, like a surgeon dissecting the human machine, probes for the roots of sleeplessness in the very fabric of our being.  It whispers of genes passed down through generations, of the rhythmic dance of neurotransmitters in the brain, of the hypothalamus, a lone sentinel guarding the gates to slumber.  There are stories, for example, of neurons bathed in the glow of orexin, their whispers controlling the flow of wakefulness and rest. Studies on mice, those creatures so often our proxies in unraveling the mysteries of life, suggest that the GABAB receptor plays a pivotal role in this dance.  When activated, it ushers in the embrace of sleep.  But what if this receptor falters, its whispers silenced, its embrace withdrawn?  Could it be that the very blueprint of our being, etched in our genes, holds the key to our sleepless nights?

But the story doesn't end there. The sociocultural model, a cartographer of human experience, reminds us that our sleep is also shaped by the world around us.  It speaks of the tapestry woven by race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and the ever-shifting sands of time.  It tells us that the shadows of our past, the burdens we bear, the anxieties that gnaw at our souls, all contribute to the symphony of sleeplessness.

These two maps, the biological and the sociocultural, offer glimpses into the labyrinth of insomnia. They show us that sleep is not merely a biological imperative but a cultural construct, a delicate dance between our genes and our environment.

The wind rattled the bones of the world, carrying whispers of a sound not heard but felt - a sound that lived in the marrow of things. This was the land of the unheard. Here, the silence was a living presence, a shroud wrapped tight around the ears. It was the silence of the empty road stretching into the gray dust, the silence of the wind whistling through the canyons of broken buildings, the silence of a world that had forgotten how to speak. This was Central Auditory Processing Disorder. Not a failure of the ear, but a failure of the mind to hear, a failure to make sense of the symphony of sounds.

The ears worked, but the music died in the labyrinthine halls of the brain. Words blurred, sounds tangled, and the world became a cacophony of half-heard whispers.  It was a battlefield, this place where sound went to die. The boy with the quiet eyes, the teacher saw it in his struggle, in the way he turned his head, straining to catch the lost syllables, in the way he stumbled over words like they were stones on a treacherous path.

The teacher, a weathered hand in a glove of worn leather, knew the signs. The child who seemed to be daydreaming, the one who couldn't follow directions, the one who struggled with rhyming games and word searches.  They were the echoes, the ghosts of sound, lost in the static of their own minds. 

There were no tests for this, no maps to guide them through the maze. Only observation, intuition, and a desperate hope to find the missing notes, the fragments of sound that the world denied them.

The play, Twelfth Night, speaks of a truth: disguise, though it can weave a web of deceit for a time,  eventually unravels, leaving the wearer bare. A man or woman can lose themselves in the borrowed skin, a hollow echo of what they once were.  To shed the guise, to reclaim one's true face, is to risk the sting of exposure, the chill of alienation.  For some, the world may accept the revelation, shrug and move on. But others, their trust broken,  will recoil, their eyes filled with the ice of betrayal.

The pretense of gender, a particularly treacherous game, lays bare the heart of the matter. Why, one must ask, would a soul choose to abandon their own identity, to walk in the shadow of another?  In Viola's case, the answer lies in the harsh realities of a world hostile to women. "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..."  (5.1.247-249 )  A stranger in a strange land, she dons the armor of masculinity, seeking safety in a man's guise. But this protection comes at a price. The embrace of sisterhood, a lifeline for women, is severed. She walks alone.  And worse, Olivia, blinded by the mask, falls in love with the illusion, mistaking Cesario for the man he is not.  "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." (5.1.138)  

And what of the unspoken desires that simmer beneath the surface? Orsino, the Duke, drawn to Cesario, cries out, "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me." (5.1. 260-261) Is Olivia's love a reflection of her own hidden yearnings, or a mockery of societal expectations?  Twelfth Night, a mirror to the age, offers a glimpse into the complexities of the human heart, where deception can both reveal and conceal the truth.  Olivia's swift shift of affection from Cesario to Sebastian suggests a shallowness that mocks genuine love. She treats Cesario/Viola as a family member, a distant echo of the passion she once held.  "A sister, you are she." (5.1.315)

The dust clung to everything in South West Africa, a shroud over the land that choked the sun and settled deep in the bones.  The German Reich had carved its mark on these bones too, a bloody brand seared into the flesh of the land.  They spoke of genocide, of the Ovaherero and Nama decimated, their names whispered like curses on the wind.  But empires, like men, are composed of more than nightmares.  There were others, too, those who sought knowledge, who yearned to unravel the secrets of the world.  They came to the colony, these men of learning, seeking to impose order on the chaos, to bring light to the darkness.

And the light they brought was uneven, fractured by the harsh realities of the land and the men who ruled it. In East Africa, the Germans, like iron-wrought hands, reached out and built schools, fostering a literate generation. But here, in this desolate land, they turned their backs. The task of education, that vital spark of civilization, was left to the missionaries, frail flickering candles in the vast expanse of ignorance. 

The government, its heart cold and calculating, poured its resources into educating its own, building schools for the white men who claimed ownership of this land.  The native Africans, their voices drowned out by the clatter of progress, were left to wander in the shadows.

The echoes of this neglect reverberated long after the German flag had been lowered.  While other colonies boasted of educated Africans, here, in this land of dust and despair, the majority remained untouched, shrouded in the veil of illiteracy.

This is the story of South West Africa, a story of contrasts and contradictions.  A story of a land scarred by violence and a people yearning for knowledge.  A story whispered in the wind, carried on the back of the dust.

The music they called Popular, in the hundred years since its birth, had birthed so many sounds, so many names, it was like trying to catalog the stars. Rap, Rock, Country, Jazz, Folk - each a constellation in its own right, each with its own nebulae of subgenres swirling beneath. But Heavy Metal, born of the rock that came before, clawed its way up, a beast with a heart of fire and a tongue of steel. Forty years it had raged, and within that time, it had become a galaxy unto itself.

It was expressive, this metal. The darkness it wore was a cloak, a shield, but within it, a storm of emotion roiled. Joy and rage, despair and defiance, all given voice in the clang of guitars and the thunder of drums. It was diverse, too, a tapestry woven from a thousand threads. From the moment it first took hold, folks began to see the potential, the ways to twist and bend it to their will. Subgenres bloomed, each a unique flower in the metal garden, and still, the growth continued.

Today, the metal landscape is a sprawling wilderness. The lines blur, the boundaries fade. So many branches, so many riffs, so many voices, it's hard to say where metal truly begins and ends. But to understand the music that fills the airwaves now, the music that seeps into your bones, you have to understand its origins. It started with a spark, a fire in the heart of rebellion, and grew into a tidal wave.

Metal is a movement, not just a genre. It's a hunger for something more, a yearning for the raw, the real. More bass, more volume, more fury. Less pretense, more soul poured into every note. It's a music of grit and grind, where the musicians are masters of their instruments, their fingers dancing across strings like wraiths.

And it's a music born of darkness, a child of the night. It's haunted by the ghosts of drugs and despair, echoes of a psychedelic era where boundaries were broken and reality itself was questioned. It has its roots in the Romantic era's obsession with the dark side of the human experience. Lyrics like those penned by Byrne in "Helter Skelter" speak to this darkness, a descent into madness, a glimpse into the abyss.

This song, with its swirling, discordant melody and its lyrics that speak of chaos and confusion, it's a harbinger of things to come. It's a bridge between the light and the darkness, a turning point in music history. The Beatles, those icons of pop, dared to explore the shadows, to confront the darkness within. They surprised the world, and in doing so, they unleashed a force that would change music forever.

The canvas breathes the silence of a man's longing.  Henri Rousseau, before the world knew surreal dreamscapes, he was painting his own. The Dream, that picture from ‘10, it ain’t just a woman awestruck by some fantastical land. It’s Rousseau himself, reaching for something just out of grasp. Recognition, acceptance, the whispered praise of the art world he hungered for.  A hunger born in the heart of a man with no fancy schooling, a customs man, a gabelou they called him, toiling away till forty.  He dreamt of brushstrokes that spoke, not the gruff strokes of a man who’d seen worlds beyond canvas.

His life, it was a canvas itself. Born in Laval, his father a man of trade, he found no solace in hammers and nails.  He yearned for color, for light, for stories whispered on the wind.  Then came the deaths, the toll of loved ones, leaving him with a daughter, Julia, and a soul heavy with grief.  Painting, it became his refuge, a way to mend the broken pieces.

He wasn't like the others, the ones who romanticized the peasant life on canvas.  He was the peasant, the man in the street, his dreams as raw and real as the paint he bled onto the cloth. He saw the world with eyes that yearned for something more, something beyond the mundane drudgery of his days.

The art world, it was a beast with sharp teeth and a hunger for the new, the different.  And Rousseau, he was a man who craved its approval. He saw the giants of the time, Matisse, Picasso, their names whispered in hushed tones, their works hung in gilded galleries. He wanted that, that recognition, that validation.

But there was a struggle within him, a battle between conformity and individuality. Should he mimic the styles he admired, the ones that pleased the critics, or should he stay true to his own vision, even if it meant remaining in the shadows?  The Dream, it was a reflection of that struggle, a woman lost in a world of her own making, searching for something, yet afraid to reach out.

The world’s sharp thinkers, they say, see a kinship between good and beauty. Truth and grace, they whisper, bound by some unseen thread. Keats himself, in his ode to the Grecian urn, puts it plain: “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.”  We learn much in this life, facts and figures, lessons hard-won. But beauty and rightness, these things, they seem to find us, not the other way around. They’re whispered in the dark, not taught in classrooms.  Both, in their way, try to name the unnameable. We study art and morals, seeking to explain what makes a song sing or an action just. But the heart of it, the core, it shimmers just beyond the reach of words.

Take the Mona Lisa, for instance. We dissect her, praise her brushstrokes, her pose, the way light catches her smile. But do we truly touch the soul of that painting? No. There’s a place beneath the surface, a space where words fail and a hush falls. It’s the same with right and wrong. We build codes, pronounce judgments, but at the heart of it, there’s a feeling, a knowing that transcends the rules. Flannery O’Connor, her words like shards of glass, saw this truth:  “A story is a way to say something that can’t be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” Literature, like morality, it aches with a depth that language can’t fully grasp. Wittgenstein, he understood this too, saying, "Ethics cannot be expressed. Ethics is transcendental.”

This is the power of art and morality, the thing that binds them. They reach us in a way that defies logic, in a realm where feeling reigns.  McKean, he said it right, “Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there.”  And those values, they echo the deepest parts of ourselves, the whispers of our souls.  They are the truth, the beauty, the only things that truly matter.

The land they called Germany now, it held itself up stiff and strong. A country stitched together from the shadows of the Alps in München to the stark bones of the Baltic in Kiel. One culture ran through it all, from the cobbled streets of Köln on the Rhine, through the heart of the country, to the Saxon city of Dresden crouched upon the Elbe. It was a culture born of many pieces, of tribes long gone, each one leaving its mark upon the land. 

Germania, the name itself echoed with the ghosts of those ancient peoples. Where it came from, who first spoke it, that was a question gnawed at by scholars and whispered by the wind. Tacitus, he wrote of the Tungrians, a tribe that called themselves Germans before they crossed the Rhine and clashed with the Gauls.  Caesar, the Roman, he called them “Germanus,” a word taken from the mouths of the Gauls themselves, a way to set them apart, the conquered and the unconquered. Some say it meant neighbor, in the tongue of the Gauls. Caesar, in his own words, wrote of them in the Gallic Wars, "Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles."

Others say it came from the spear they wielded, the ger, or perhaps from the Irish word “garim,” meaning "to shout," a people known for their voices, loud and raw. The truth, like the wind, it shifts and blows, leaving only whispers in its wake.

Tacitus, he wrote of them as a people untouched, pure, untouched by the tide of migration. He painted a picture of a land where the sky was harsh, the land wild, and the people fierce. He wondered why anyone would leave the warmth of Rome for such a place, for Germania. A land where the wind carried the ghosts of battles long past. 

And the Romans, they came and went, taking what they could, leaving their mark on the land, but never truly settling. They traded, they fought, they took their spoils, and then they returned to their own empire, leaving the Germans to their own fate. 

But the Germans, they were a people of the land, they knew it like the back of their hand. They traded their goods, their skills, and sometimes, their blood, serving in the Roman legions. They were a people woven from the threads of many stories, their past a tapestry of shadows and light, waiting to be unraveled.

Downward, the stare. A blankness. Comprehension, a hard glint in the eye, but no feeling. Just the slow, methodical turning of the mind, dissecting the scene. Thoughts, fleeting shadows, flitting in and out of consciousness, never quite taking hold. A clean, cold efficiency, like a knife slicing through air. 

There'd been that book once, "The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain," a gift from a man who knew, or thought he knew, about art. It'd promised to unlock the secrets, to teach the mind how to see. How to strip away the clutter, the overwhelming detail, and find the essence.  To see a bowl of fruit not as a bowl of fruit, but as a simple arrangement of shapes, a study in light and shadow.

He looked down at the scene before him, but the artist's frame wouldn't come.  The world was too much, too raw, too full of the things that lived and died and rotted. Picasso, Monet, the Renaissance masters, they'd all had their colors, their phases, their stories. His would be different. His would be brown. 

The hand reached out, a thief in the night, grasping the implement of creation. Muscles tensed, a tremor ran through the arm, and the hand plunged into the swirling depths.  Water, clear and cold, embraced the hand, a mirror reflecting the image of a soul drowning in its own grime.  A moment of stillness, then a spasm, a flailing, a desperate attempt to make something, anything, out of the formless void. 

The mop, a limp appendage held in a trembling hand, the green tie a noose around the neck.  Eyes fixed on the unholy offering, a monument to human waste, a silent scream of disgust.  A flush, a sigh, a futile attempt at purification.  The toilet paper, a flimsy shield against the horrors, wrapped around the hand like a shroud.

The road bleeds young.  Takes them like a hawk in the sky, those eyes bright and eager behind the wheel.  The doctors say it's the way their brains are wired, still soft, still forming.  They call it "risk-taking" but it's more like a hunger, a need to be seen, to feel alive.  And the road, it just swallows them whole.

They say it's the inexperience too, the lack of miles under their belts.  They don't know the feel of the asphalt, the whispers of the wind through the trees, the way the rain can turn a highway into a river of glass.  They think they're invincible, these young drivers, until they're not.

And they go with their peers, close huddled in the car, like lambs to the slaughter.  They laugh and they sing, oblivious to the danger.  One wrong move, one moment of distraction, and it's over.

California tried to stop it, these provisional licenses, curfews, passenger limits.  But it's a band-aid on a gunshot wound.  The truth is, they're not ready.  Not for the responsibility, not for the weight of the world on their shoulders.  There's a man, Zuckerman, says even eighteen is too young.  Says their brains are still learning, still forming.  That the need for thrills, the hunger for danger, it's hardwired.

So what do we do?  Push them into the fire, let them learn the hard way?  Or do we wait?  Wait until their brains are forged, until the recklessness fades, until the road no longer beckons them like a siren song?

They're coming, these young drivers, millions of them.  The Baby Boomers' children, ready to take their place on the asphalt.  And if we don't do something, if we don't protect them, if we don't teach them the respect the road demands, then the road will keep taking them.  One by one.

We need to make a stand.  We need to tell them, "No."  Not yet.  Not until you're ready.

The Library of Congress holds a collection of Edison's early films, ghosts flickering across time. Fifteen trick films, a history lesson in illusions, from 1895 to 1901.  I watched them, each one a whispered secret of a vanishing age.  Most clung to the old ways, bound by a poetics of artifice. 

Their stage was the frame, a proscenium arch barring the way to anything else. No wandering eye of the camera, no movement beyond the rigid confines. Long shots, medium shots, that was all they knew. Like a play, the audience was meant to see it all at once, no closer, no further.  

The actors, confined by this stage, danced a slow, sideways jig. Their steps like shadows across a dusty floorboard.  In “Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel” (1900), they come and go, flitting across the frame like startled birds, but never truly leaving.  

Close-ups, the intimate whispers of film, were absent. No probing gaze into the depths of a soul. The camera held aloof, a silent judge, seeing it all, but never truly touching.

And the films themselves, short bursts of conjured magic, lived and died within a single shot. A minute, maybe less, a fleeting glimpse into a world constructed of smoke and mirrors.  The story, if there was one, unfolded in a quick flash, like a magician's hand, revealing a secret then whisking it away.

But there were exceptions, whispers of change in the wind. The very notion of a "shot" could be stretched, manipulated.  "The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots" (1895)  a prime example. The severed head, a shock of darkness, appearing and disappearing, a trick played on the eye. A single “shot,” but a whisper of a thousand fragmented moments, stitched together to weave a spell.

The man John Taylor,  he came from Carolina,  a man of the soil,  a farmer. But the land, it didn't just feed him, it shaped him. Shaped him into a man who spoke out,  his voice ringing with the conviction of a man who'd seen the earth bleed and the sky bleed too.  He believed in the Republic,  believed in men free to tend their own furrows,  free from the grasping tendrils of government. 

This belief,  it was the seed from which all his other thoughts grew.  Sovereignty,  the Constitution,  even the courts,  all were filtered through this lens,  this agrarian vision of a world where the soil was king and the man was its steward. He saw a chance in these new United States,  a chance to build something true, something untainted by the old ways.  No ancient gods, no feudal chains, just men and the land, bound by a contract forged in the sweat of their brows. He believed in rights,  natural rights,  rights that belonged to every man simply by virtue of being born. He believed these rights were a chain,  each one linked to the others,  and if one broke,  the whole chain would snap.  And government,  it was like a hungry beast,  always ready to snatch at those chains, to pull men down from their rightful place.

He saw the good and the bad in men,  a duality woven into the fabric of their being.  He spoke of it often, this duality,  how government,  being man-made,  would inevitably reflect that duality.  He called for a government that acknowledged this truth,  a government that protected the good and contained the bad. A government that fostered the land,  protected property,  and kept greed in check. He believed a government run by men,  even the best of men, would always be susceptible to the lure of power,  that their hands would reach for more than they were given.  But he also believed that men,  in their hearts,  yearned for something more than power. They yearned for freedom,  for the chance to live their lives according to their own lights.

He was a man of the Constitution,  a strict constructionist,  believing that the government should only have the powers explicitly granted to it. Anything more,  he argued,  was a slippery slope,  a path leading to tyranny. He saw the danger in a large,  powerful Federal government,  a government that could easily become despotic,  a government that would drain the lifeblood from the land and the people. 

He looked to the Declaration of Independence,  to the words that declared the United States a union of sovereign states,  and saw in it a blueprint for a government that respected the autonomy of its people. It was a government of,  by,  and for the people,  not a government that ruled over them. The government,  he believed,  was a mere servant,  a tool to be used to protect the rights of the individual,  not a master to be obeyed.

The numbers in the white-light box, Figure 17, told a story. A steep drop in the third month. A kind of falling away. Disheartening, it was. Why it happened, hard to say. Winter's grip on the campus, cold and unforgiving, likely kept folks from biking or walking. December, the semester's end, a blur of deadlines and papers and packing things away. The commuter log, maybe, a thing left behind in the rush. Then the holidays, a season of lights and tinsel and a break from the grind. A long month of stillness. Classes resumed in January, but the numbers stayed low. February, a mystery.

Maybe, like a fire, the project burned bright at first, then settled into embers. A natural thing. To fight that, we cooked up the Carpool Challenge, a blaze of competition in March. It worked, the numbers climbed again. But the fight, it was there. Holding onto the flame, against the seasons, against the pull of routine.

The truth is, folks love their cars. The freedom, the independence, it's woven into the fabric of things. To get them to leave it behind, you gotta offer something more. We gave out goodies, gift certificates for coffee and meals and massages, even a bookstore or two. Bigger prizes, though, might have done more. A bike, a hybrid, even a sleek electric car, that might have pulled folks in. The prizes, they stayed the same, a steady drip. But imagine, a gradual escalation. A whisper of a bike in December, then a hybrid in January, the electric car a prize for the bold in February. Maybe then the numbers wouldn't have fallen.

The ticker, IHF, it whispers on the wire, a cage for a phantom.  An ETF, they call it, a security, a basket of hopes woven from the threads of a hundred companies.  Like a spider’s web, it catches the market’s fly, but with less grace, less artistry.  They say it tracks an index, mimics the dance of the market, but what market? The one where men in suits whisper numbers and fortunes are lost and found like stray dogs in the night?

This IHF, it promises diversification, a shield against the storm.  But is it a shield or a shroud? It offers the liquidity of a single stock, the bite of a quick trade, the comfort of owning a sliver of a thousand dreams. But at what cost?

They speak of expense ratios, of commissions paid, of the cold hand of the market taking its due.  They speak of benefits, but benefits for whom?  The men in suits, the ones with eyes like vultures, circling the carcass of the unwary?

The ten who hold the reins, the ten who form the backbone of this beast – they’re the ones to watch.  Sixty-three percent, they say, of the IHF’s weight rests on their shoulders.  A kingmaker’s dominion, a cabal of shadows.

They dangle a promise of returns, a whisper of a higher yield, a lower beta.  But is it truth or a siren’s song, luring the innocent to their doom?  The numbers, they dance and swirl, a hypnotic waltz of percentages and probabilities.  But the heart, the human heart, it knows better.

The true test lies not in the cold logic of the spreadsheet, but in the fire of experience.  To own the ten, to hold them in your hand, not as a fraction, not as a shadow, but as whole, living things.  That is the only true measure.

The land of dreams, a place Poe called Thulé. A word borrowed, he said, from the ancients, from Virgil’s pen. An island north, they said, beyond the known world, where the Greeks had set its edge. But the whispers of a darker source, a Germanic one, echo in the shadows. Poe, a man steeped in the lore of the Germans, a kinship with their words and their ways.

Some say he was a student of Goethe, a shadow walker in the woods of his imagination. Karl J. Arndt, a scholar of the inkwell, sees the kinship in the lines of Poe’s “Politian” and Goethe’s “Mignon,” a weaving of echoes and similarities.

Goethe, the master of words, the weaver of “Faust,” a tale spun in two parts, darkness and light. In the second, a poem called “The King of Thulé.” A king, bereft of his queen, drinks deep from a goblet gifted by her hand. Grief consumes him, a slow tide pulling him under. He, too, seeks the edge of the world, a cliff overlooking the sea. He casts the goblet, a symbol of his loss, into the waves, closes his eyes, and joins the darkness.

Poe’s “Dream-Land,” a landscape of shadows, a king haunted by the ghosts of his past, a world drained of color, of joy. One might see in this king a reflection of Poe himself, a doppelganger, a mirror held up to his own sorrow, his own escape into the bottle. And the words “Thulé,” echoed in “The Pit and the Pendulum,” like a whispered warning from the abyss.

Thulé, a bookend in Poe’s poem, a haunting refrain. A land of dreams, a place of loss, a path to the edge. 

Poe, a man who walked in the shadows, who knew the heart of darkness, who found solace in the company of ghosts. He found in Goethe, a kindred spirit, a fellow traveler on the road to the unknown.

The law in this here California, it says a customer can get more than just pocket change if they fall and break their bones over a spilled applesauce.  It speaks of 'punitive damages' - a fancy name for making the store pay extra, real extra, for being careless. But to get those, the customer, Miss Palmer, she gotta prove the store manager, Mr. Martin, didn't just make a mistake, he was downright mean.  

Now, a judge ain't gonna toss this claim out quick, not on account of a spill and a broken back. To get those punitive damages, Miss Palmer gotta show that Mr. Martin knew good and well that not cleanin' up that mess could hurt somebody, but he done it anyway, on purpose. Like he was willfully blind, seein' the danger but choosin' to ignore it. 

See, she's gonna say that Mr. Martin should have known better.  He'd been told about spills before - other folks had slipped and fallen. It happened more than once, in fact. Six times in the year before Miss Palmer went tumblin' down. And yet, he dismissed it, said he was too busy eatin' his dinner. 

Now, whether the judge sees his actions as downright despicable, that's a tougher sell. But with all those accidents, it's a story that might stick.

It all happened on a Wednesday, October 13th, 5:00 p.m. Rich Wayne, a fella workin' at the store, told Mr. Martin about the applesauce spill.  Mr. Martin, he just said, "Dinner break, gotta eat." Then, 15 minutes later, Mary Haddigan, another employee, gave him the same heads-up, same answer. 

And then, at half past five, Miss Palmer came along, slipped, and went down hard.  Back cracked.  Now she's suing the store for all the pain and heartache, and maybe even some extra punishment, for the store's careless ways.

The dust of four years settled on the classroom, the air still thick with the heat of debate.  Islam. The word itself hung heavy, a question mark in the air. Was it a religion of peace, or a wellspring of violence? The question, it seemed, only deepened in the wake of the falling towers, a knife twisting in the gut of a nation. The airwaves, once choked with suspicion, now whispered of tolerance, of understanding. A black man named Obama, with a name that tasted of the East, rose to the highest office. A world turned, it seemed, on its axis.

The Prophet's story, though, that was a different beast. It clung to me, a whisper in the dark. The man I'd imagined, the sword-wielding conqueror, the one who forced his faith upon the world, was gone. In his place stood a figure of meekness, a martyr misunderstood, drawing people to him like moths to a flame. A whisper of doubt flickered. Was this the truth, or a carefully crafted image?

The parallels with the life of Jesus, they haunted me. The loaves and fishes, multiplied on command, echoed through the ages, a story spun for both.  Was this a subtle theft, a borrowing of divinity, a way to elevate Muhammad to the same plane as Christ? The thought sat like a stone in my stomach. 

Then there were the stories, whispered from one man to another, each retelling a blur of hearsay.  These were supposed to be testaments, proof of the Prophet's truth, but they felt hollow, lacking the weight of direct experience.  

But the thing that gnawed at me the most was the portrait they painted of Muhammad.  A gentle soul, wise and humble, a beacon of light. History, though, whispered a different tale, a story of conquest and violence.  A man, perhaps, who used his faith to build an empire.  Did the faithful know this history?  Or had they chosen to embrace a myth, a carefully curated image of their prophet?

The dust of the world settled on the bones of what Jesus preached.  His voice, once a clarion call, faded to a whisper in the wind of time.  Christianity, born in his image,  grew, twisted, and spread, a vine choking the saplings of his original intent.  The world turned, a wheel ever grinding, and the light of progress cast long shadows on the past.

Old ways clung to the bones of men, resistant to the wind of change. But the tide was turning.  A hunger stirred, a yearning for something lost.  A thirst for the pure spring of Jesus' words, unmuddied by the centuries of accretion.

Like a slow, inexorable flood, this yearning would rise.  It would wash over the land, erasing the mortar of dogma, stone by stone, layer by layer.  The churches, those grand monuments to tradition, would stand watch as the tide receded, revealing a truth buried beneath the silt of time.

A new dawn would break, a return to the source.  A world where the echoes of Jesus' voice rang clear, unburdened by the weight of centuries.  The churches, though still standing, would become vessels for this new understanding, their sermons echoing the simplicity of the original message.

From sea to shining sea, the faithful would gather, not as denominations, but as a single, unified voice.  Differences would dissolve, replaced by a shared understanding, a common ground forged in the crucible of history.

History itself seemed to turn in cycles, a slow, relentless dance of progress and regress.  Like the Roman Empire, once the persecutor, now the convert, the world would turn again.  The chains of the past would loosen, the shackles of tradition would fall away, and the world would be reborn in the image of the carpenter's son.  The path to this future was paved with a single, unwavering truth: a willingness to see Jesus' words not as literal pronouncements, but as a timeless reflection of the human spirit.

And then, as always, there was the beginning, the source, the echo that resonated through the ages.  Judaism, the wellspring of faith, where monotheism took root, where the scriptures whispered promises of a coming savior.

The smoke, it rose black against the sky like a shroud.  The factories, they breathed it out, this river of soot, staining the world with the greed that fueled them. Men, they craved only more, always more, and they'd grind the life out of anything to get it. The owners, they saw the workers not as men, but as cogs, expendable parts in a machine built only for profit. 

Sinclair, he saw it. He painted a picture of Packingtown, a place where the stench of blood and decay hung thick in the air.  A place where men, their bodies broken and spirits crushed, toiled for scraps of their lives.  The line between man and beast blurred in those factories, a butcher's shop more than a place of work.

The men, they worked till they bled, till their hands were raw and their backs bent double.  For what? A pittance, a cruel joke in the face of the wealth the owners amassed.  A day's notice, that's all it took to cast them out, adrift in a sea of poverty.  

No laws to shield them, no hand to lift them. Unions, they promised help, but proved to be wolves in sheep's clothing, leeches feeding on the misery they claimed to fight.

Packingtown, it was a cage, a prison of brick and steel. The workers, they were slaves in a gilded cage, their lives consumed by the insatiable hunger of the machine.  They toiled, they suffered, they died, all for the sake of the owners' insatiable desire for more.  

Sinclair, he saw the darkness, the gnawing hunger at the heart of man. He showed the world the beast within, the beast that feasts on the weak and spits on the fallen.

The world of men, it’s painted in colors, each shade a whispered truth. Fitzgerald, he knew this. He knew how to stain the canvas of his story with hues that bled into the reader’s soul, leaving a taste of ash and regret on the tongue. Take his Gatsby. A man obsessed with the shimmer of things, with the allure of the spectral green light across the bay. But Fitzgerald, he didn't stop there. He layered his story with shades of gray, of white, of a fading pink, each color a ghost story whispering in the dark.

White, that spectral purity, it clung to Daisy like a shroud. White flannels, white dresses, white faces. A uniformity that suffocated the soul. Like the endless expanse of the city, cold and sterile. Gray, it seeped into the edges of things, the forgotten faces in the crowd, the names scrawled on Nick’s timetable. A dull ache of emptiness, the weight of forgotten dreams.

Fitzgerald, he knew the power of these colors. He used them to tell a story of a man chasing a ghost, a phantom of a love lost in the bleak landscape of the past. Daisy, she was the epitome of this white-washed illusion, a beautiful shell, empty and hollow. And Gatsby, he was the fool who chased the mirage, a man consumed by the grayness, the endless pursuit of an unattainable dream.

The land sits heavy, a sun-baked weight in the San Diego hills.  A hundred and sixty acres of chaparral, brush choked with the ghosts of forgotten ranch hands and the whispers of a time before man. Tomatoes and lemons, they call it a bounty, but the land knows other truths.  There's a hunger here, a gnawing in the dust, that can't be fed by the sun alone. 

The oaks stand sentinel, their gnarled limbs clawing at a sky bleached white by the endless sun.  The air hangs thick with the scent of sage and dust, a shroud over the bones of this forgotten place.  They say the earth remembers.  And this land, it remembers the rasp of hoof on parched earth, the crackle of a flint fire, the slow, steady pulse of a life lived closer to the marrow.

They talk of organic, of a market hungry for the purity of the soil, the unsullied taste of a tomato kissed by the sun.  But the money, it's a fickle thing, doesn't come easy in these parts. The whispers in the wind speak of a different kind of wealth, the wealth of the wild, the whispers of a kangaroo rat darting through the brush, the mournful call of a frog lost in the twilight.

There's a plan, they say, a blueprint for salvation.  A web spun to protect the creatures of this forgotten land, to thread them back into the tapestry of life. But words on paper are brittle things, easily torn by the harsh winds of reality.

This land, it holds its secrets close, buried beneath layers of dust and time. It craves a different kind of stewardship, a touch that doesn't seek to exploit, but to understand, to listen to the whispers of the wind and the rustle of the sage.  The true wealth lies not in profit, but in the quiet communion with the earth, in the dance of life and death under the relentless gaze of the sun.

The wind folded across the table, a silent thing, carrying with it the dust of a thousand reckonings.  Culture, it whispered, a scalpel carving through bone and sinew, a blade that could break or build a man. It weren't some static thing, some painted signpost on the road. It was the hollowness in a man’s eye, the way he held his hand, the story etched in the lines of his face.  You couldn't squeeze it into a box, label it and hang it on a wall.  To say "all Russians were stubborn" or "all Japanese accommodating" was to spit on the wind, a truth as fleeting as smoke. 

It was the unspoken things that mattered. The weight of history in a handshake. The way a silence stretched, thick and heavy, between two men.  It was in the way a man's eyes held yours, searching, measuring, seeing not just your face but the ghost of your soul. 

You approached a foreign land, a foreign culture, with your own baggage, your own ghosts. You saw it through the lens of your own experience, but that was a flawed lens, cracked and stained. It was a dance, a delicate balance of respect and mistrust. You had to learn their language, not just the words, but the silences between them, the unspoken rules, the hidden meanings.  You had to understand their gods, their demons, their fears. 

And you had to be willing to let go of your own.

The fool, the Psalm says, he's said it in his heart: "There is no God."  That's where Anselm starts, with that empty space, that echoing silence where God ought to be. And Aquinas, too, he sees that same emptiness, though he sets about filling it not with faith, but with reason.  They both aim for the same target, this God of the Bible, this God of the Book, and the question hangs: who hits the bullseye?  

But first, a reckoning. To compare their shots, we have to assume they both believe in the same target.  A God shaped by scripture, a God with the attributes laid out in those ancient pages. Anything else, any other God, would be a phantom, a shadow in the distance, not worthy of this kind of scrutiny. 

Anselm, he speaks of God as something already known, a truth nestled deep in the mind.  He says, look within, and you'll find him. This is a God not of the stars or the stones, but of the soul, a God glimpsed in the quiet spaces between thought and feeling.  He calls it faith, this knowing without proof, this acceptance of the unseen.  

Aquinas, he wants something more solid, something you can touch, something that doesn't rely on whispers in the dark.  He builds his case on five pillars: change, cause, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony.  Each one, a brick in the wall, a step towards proving God's existence through logic, through the observable world. No need for blind leaps, no need for faith. Just reason, pure and simple.

But both men, they wrestle with the same question, the same fundamental mystery.  And neither, perhaps, provides a final answer.  Anselm's God is a whisper in the soul, a truth too vast to grasp with the mind alone.  Aquinas' God is a construct, a masterpiece of logic, but is it enough to satisfy the human heart?

The dust of ages, it clung thick to the bones of the world. A prince, they called him. Born in the shadow of the fifth century, a man marked for something more. Buddha. A name that would echo through the years, a whisper on the wind. He cast aside the trappings of kingship, sought solace in the quiet spaces between breaths. His words, they became the bedrock of a faith. Theravada, they called it, the oldest, truest path. Twenty-five hundred years, the sun has risen and set on its tenets. Yet, the world shifts, the light changes.

Even in the land of Lanka, where the waters are cut each year in a silent ceremony, a ritual born not of Buddha's own tongue, but of time and circumstance. Monks and laymen alike, they gather, a river of devotion flowing in a current not hewn by the Buddha himself. The differences, they seep into the very marrow of the faith. From the outward forms, to the heart of what it means to be free.

To understand this, we must speak of forces. Internal and external. The whispers of dissent within the fold, the echoes of change from outside its walls. Hostile forces, they seek to wound, to diminish. Benign, they tread lightly, unaware of the ripples they cast.

The core of Theravada, it lies in the refuge of the triple gem. The Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha. The Dhamma, the spoken word, the three baskets of wisdom. Suttas, Vinaya, and Abhidhamma. Metaphysics, the nature of reality, the dance between impermanence and suffering. Anatta, the absence of a permanent self. Dukkha, the inherent pain of existence. Anicca, the constant flux of all things.

The cycle of birth and death, Sansara, it grinds on. Fueled by lobha, desire, dosa, hatred, and moha, delusion. But through understanding, through the four noble truths, we can break free. Dukkha, the truth of suffering. Samudaya, the cause of suffering, attachment. Nirodha, the cessation of suffering. Magga, the path to liberation. The eightfold path, a map to navigate the treacherous terrain of the mind.

These are the seeds planted by the Buddha. They have taken root in the fertile ground of countless hearts. But the wind of change blows, and the landscape shifts.
